JS is useful
but often overused

HTML & CSS are lighter

  • No JS
  • No build tools
  • No npm packages
  • Just HTML & CSS

HTML Tricks

  • Content Targeting
  • Accordians
  • Form Validations

Content Targeting

<!-- Links to another page or website -->
<a href="/about">Other page</a>
<a href="https://google.com">Other website</a>

<!-- A File or Resource -->
<a href="/img/my_image.jpg" download>Download Image</a>
<a href="/resources/info.pdf">View PDF</a>

<!-- An ID -->
<a href="#main">Skip to main content</a>
<a href="/about#contact">Contact the team</a>
.my_element:target {
	background: pink;
}
  • Go to demo to show page sections

:target

Full Disclosure‚Ä¶

  • This involves working with URL hash values and not a great alternative most of the time
  • Not great for accessibility

Accordians

<details>
	<summary>This bit is clickable to expand/collapse</summary>
	<p>This content is hidden but can then be expanded or re-collapsed.</p>
</details>
  • Switch to live demo

details and summary elements

Full Disclosure‚Ä¶

  • These are good
  • When not supported they display as open

Form Validations

Required Fields

<input name="email" required />

Data Format

<input type="date" name="due_date">

<input type="tel" name="phone" pattern="[0-9]{3}-[0-9]{3}-[0-9]{4}" />
  • Go to form and show validations and formats

input[type="tel"]

[pattern]

Full Disclosure‚Ä¶

  • Limited validation capabilities
  • JS adds more powerful capabilities

CSS Tricks

  • Nesting
  • Range Slider
  • Testimonials
  • Toggle Switch
  • Image Carousel

Nesting

div {
	& p {
		color: red;
	}
}

nesting

Range Slider

<input type="range" min="0" max="10" />
<input type="range" min="0" max="10" list="options" />
<datalist id="options">
	<option value="0">Not good</option>
	<option value="5">ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è</option>
	<option value="10">Stupendous</option>
</datalist>
  • Go to demo

input[type="range"]

datalist

:has

Testimonials

<input type="radio" id="t_1" name="testimonials" />
<label for="t_1">Quote 1</label>
<blockquote>
	<!-- Quote here -->
</blockquote>

div:has(p:nth-child(4)) {
	--children: 4;
}

div:has(p:nth-child(5)) {
	--children: 5;
}
  • Go to demo

:has

:not

grid

Full Disclosure‚Ä¶

  • Messing with form inputs for not forms isn‚Äôt great
  • Would recommend adding some aria labels and roles to give more information
  • May be confusing for why people are clicking radio buttons to change testimonials
  • :has not supported in Firefox

Toggle Switch

<div class="toggle">
	<input id="off" type="radio" name="switch" value="off" checked />
	<label for="off">Off</label>
	<input id="on" type="radio" name="switch" value="on" />
	<label for="on">On</label>
	<span class="switch"></span>
</div>
  • Go to demo
body {
	@media(prefers-color-scheme: dark) {
		--background: #0d0d0d;
		--neutral: #f7f0eb;
	}
}
  • Go to demo

:has

prefers-color-scheme

Full Disclosure‚Ä¶

  • Similar to testimonials not great for a11y as using form inputs outside a form
  • Would recommend adding aria labels to provide additional context
  • Adding JS allows triggering a more complex function and saving the value to persist on different pages and on reload
  • :has not supported in Firefox

Image Carousel

<input type="radio" name="images" value="i_1" id="img_1" checked />
<label for="img_1">Image 1</label>
<div class="image">
	<img src="img_1.jpg" alt="" />
</div>
  • Go to demo

grid

:has

Full Disclosure‚Ä¶

  • Carousels still suck
  • Not good for accessibility
  • Should turn animation off based on media querry for prefers-reduced-motion
  • Just don‚Äôt do this, use a gallery
  • :has not supported in Firefox

nojs.amyskapers.dev

JS is useful but not the answer

Can you do it with HTML?

Can you do it with CSS?

Can JS make it better?

Can some JS be removed?

Do we really need to track this?

Questions?
